items.title: Attempts not being saved when using DRF Simple JWT
items.body:
I have Axes set up with Django Rest Framework and DRF SimpleJWT. 

- Django==3.0.5
- djangorestframework==3.11.0
- djangorestframework-simplejwt==4.1.4
- django-axes==5.4.3

I've configured everything correctly (it seems). When I try log in via the Django Admin, Axes correctly saves incorrect attempts to the DB. But when I try log in via REST API & Simple Auth, incorrect attempts are identified but are not saved to the data. 

What's really strange though is that the `runserver` logging indicates the attempt was saved to the DB:

> WARNING 2020-08-15 12:20:46,516 database 81207 123145351049216 AXES: New login failure by {username: "joebloggs@example.com", ip_address: "127.0.0.1", user_agent: "Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.15; rv:80.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/80.0", path_info: "/auth/api-token-auth/"}. Creating new record in the database.

So while [the attempt object is definitely getting called correctly](https://github.com/jazzband/django-axes/blob/45109341be4db1819ed67e7fac01f2916d5b1762/axes/handlers/database.py#L143), it's just not saving to the DB.

I have no idea how this is happening though. It seems to be something to do with the signal handler maybe?

items.title: Add option to lock out by ip OR username
items.body:
Maybe I did get something wrong, but I think, that it would be possible to set increase safety options of `django-axes`.
With the default option, the attacker can have access to large stack of IP addresses (i.e. through IPv6, darkweb or botnet), and with that he can make N login attempts per IP, which might be sufficient to guess someones password.

On the other hand the other options are insufficient either (at least what I found). The `AXES_LOCK_OUT_BY_COMBINATION_USER_AND_IP` has same problem as the previous case and the `AXES_ONLY_USER_FAILURES` would allow many N*U login attempts per username to attacker with username list of the server (and he could repeat his attack after cooloff time or filling in captcha depending on server configuration).

I think, that `django-axes` needs to (at least offer, but I think it is good default) locking out based on username OR ip address attempt count. With that I mean, that after N attempts from IP address the access from that address is locked out regardless of username and after N attempts with the same username, the username is locked out regardless of IP address.

items.title: Lockout doesn't kick in if spamming requests quickly
items.body:
Hi, 

We are using your fine package with the rest framework and have found an apparent problem.

If I try to hit our auth token endpoint with invalid credentials, it correctly blocks me after the 5 attempts. But if we spam that endpoint really hard (i.e we kick off 100 requests via async), it lets ~15-20 attempts go through before locking it down. 

By printing out a few messages from the Axes signal and decorator code, it appears that the requests are being processed before the failed attempts are getting saved in the db. This may well be more to do with how DRF handles requests than the Axes code per se, but it does cause us a problem. 

I have reproduced this issue even on a local Dajngo server with the `--nothreading`  so I don't think it's related to multi-threading race conditions. But I don't really know too much about how simultaneous requests are processed in DRF. It certainly seems like it's processing some of the request before it's finished the last request. Maybe it's the signals that get processed later? 

I think our solution, for now, is going to be to throttle that endpoint (which is obviously a good thing to do anyway), but I wanted to raise the issue in case I'm doing something wrong or in case it highlights anything you can improve about Axes.

Trying to login via admin results in the following;

```bash
AttributeError: 'Settings' object has no attribute 'AXES_PROXY_ORDER'
  File "django/core/handlers/exception.py", line 34, in inner
    response = get_response(request)
  File "django/core/handlers/base.py", line 115, in _get_response
    response = self.process_exception_by_middleware(e, request)
  File "django/core/handlers/base.py", line 113, in _get_response
    response = wrapped_callback(request, *callback_args, **callback_kwargs)
  File "django/views/decorators/cache.py", line 44, in _wrapped_view_func

  File "django/utils/decorators.py", line 45, in _wrapper
    return bound_method(*args, **kwargs)
  File "django/views/decorators/debug.py", line 76, in sensitive_post_parameters_wrapper
    return view(request, *args, **kwargs)
  File "django/utils/decorators.py", line 45, in _wrapper
    return bound_method(*args, **kwargs)
  File "django/utils/decorators.py", line 142, in _wrapped_view
    response = view_func(request, *args, **kwargs)
  File "django/utils/decorators.py", line 45, in _wrapper
    return bound_method(*args, **kwargs)
  File "django/views/decorators/cache.py", line 44, in _wrapped_view_func

  File "django/views/generic/base.py", line 97, in dispatch

  File "django/views/generic/edit.py", line 141, in post
    if form.is_valid():
  File "django/forms/forms.py", line 185, in is_valid
    return self.is_bound and not self.errors
  File "django/forms/forms.py", line 180, in errors
    self.full_clean()
  File "django/forms/forms.py", line 382, in full_clean
    self._clean_form()
  File "django/forms/forms.py", line 409, in _clean_form
    cleaned_data = self.clean()
  File "django/contrib/auth/forms.py", line 205, in clean
    self.user_cache = authenticate(self.request, username=username, password=password)
  File "django/contrib/auth/__init__.py", line 73, in authenticate
    user = backend.authenticate(request, **credentials)
  File "axes/helpers.py", line 459, in inner
    return func(*args, **kwargs)
  File "axes/backends.py", line 44, in authenticate
    if AxesProxyHandler.is_allowed(request, credentials):
  File "axes/handlers/proxy.py", line 82, in is_allowed
    cls.update_request(request)
  File "axes/handlers/proxy.py", line 69, in update_request
    request.axes_ip_address = get_client_ip_address(request)
  File "axes/helpers.py", line 161, in get_client_ip_address
    proxy_order=settings.AXES_PROXY_ORDER,
  File "django/conf/__init__.py", line 80, in __getattr__
    val = getattr(self._wrapped, name)
```

Looking at `django-appconf` we assume that the issues comes from this section of code;

```python
        prefix = getattr(meta, 'prefix', getattr(meta, 'app_label', None))
        if prefix is None:
            # Figure out the prefix by looking one level up.
            # For 'django.contrib.sites.models', this would be 'sites'.

            prefix = model_module.__name__.split('.')[-2]
```

Therefore the solution to this would be to set the prefix via the meta in `AxesAppConf` to avoid sniffing the module name & be explicit about the setting prefix.

items.title: Lockouts no longer functioning after upgrading from 5.0.18 to 5.0.19
items.body:
(Hey everyone, thanks for making axes such a wonderful project!  I know a lot of hard work was put into this!)

I've been using `django-axes` for nearly a year (edit: since `4.5.x`) without any problems, and recently upgraded from `5.0.18` to `5.0.19` and my unit tests now indicate that lockouts are no longer working.

The lockouts are based on user login plus IP.  We are using `axes` with `django_rest_framework 3.8.2` and `django_allauth 0.40.0`.

Some relevant settings:
```
AUTHENTICATION_BACKENDS = (
    "axes.backends.AxesBackend",
    "django.contrib.auth.backends.ModelBackend",
    "allauth.account.auth_backends.AuthenticationBackend",
}
CACHES = {
    "default": {"BACKEND": "django.core.cache.backends.locmem.LocMemCache"},
    "axes_cache": {"BACKEND": "django.core.cache.backends.dummy.DummyCache"},
}
AXES_CACHE = "axes_cache"
AXES_LOCK_OUT_BY_COMBINATION_USER_AND_IP = True
```

With `axes 5.0.18`, after two unsuccessful local attempts against the same login:
```
[in]: from axes.models import AccessAttempt
[in]: qs = AccessAttempt.objects.all()
[in]: len(qs)
[out]: 1

[in]: attempt = qs.first()
[in]: vars(attempt)
[out]:
{'_state': <django.db.models.base.ModelState at 0x7fd6214d5dd8>,
 'id': 68,
 'user_agent': 'Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/75.0.3770.80 Safari/537.36',
 'ip_address': '127.0.0.1',
 'username': 'somebody@example.com',
 'http_accept': 'application/json',
 'path_info': '/account/login/',
 'attempt_time': datetime.datetime(2019, 11, 28, 21, 22, 5, 592513, tzinfo=<UTC>),
 'get_data': '\n---------\n',
 'post_data': 'login=somebody@example.com\n---------\nlogin=somebody@example.com',
 'failures_since_start': 2}
```

With `5.0.18` both attempts are correctly represented by the same model instance.

After upgrading to `axes 5.0.19`, when I run the same test as above:
```
[in]: qs = AccessAttempt.objects.all()
[in]: len(qs)
[out]: 2

[in]: a_1 = qs.first()
[in]: a_2 = qs.last()
[in]: vars(a_1)
[out]:
{'_state': <django.db.models.base.ModelState at 0x7f20ebe4ae48>,
 'id': 69,
 'user_agent': 'Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/75.0.3770.80 Safari/537.36',
 'ip_address': '127.0.0.1',
 'username': 'someone_else@example.com',
 'http_accept': 'application/json',
 'path_info': '/account/login/',
 'attempt_time': datetime.datetime(2019, 11, 28, 21, 27, 7, 300416, tzinfo=<UTC>),
 'get_data': '',
 'post_data': 'login=someone_else@example.com',
 'failures_since_start': 1}

[in]: vars(a_2)
[out]:
{'_state': <django.db.models.base.ModelState at 0x7f20ebe4aa20>,
 'id': 70,
 'user_agent': 'Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/75.0.3770.80 Safari/537.36',
 'ip_address': '127.0.0.1',
 'username': 'someone_else@example.com',
 'http_accept': 'application/json',
 'path_info': '/account/login/',
 'attempt_time': datetime.datetime(2019, 11, 28, 21, 27, 8, 883077, tzinfo=<UTC>),
 'get_data': '',
 'post_data': 'login=someone_else@example.com',
 'failures_since_start': 1}
```

With `5.0.19`, both attempts with the same login and IP are recorded to separate model instances and there is no lockout on subsequent attempts.

Has anyone else experienced anything like this?

items.title: Lockouts removed on refresh when deployed, works fine locally
items.body:
Thanks so much for django-axes, really appreciate all of the hard work that has gone into making this as easy to use as possible :)

I'm having a bit of trouble getting lockouts to "stick" on our Heroku deployment. We're not using caching, these are our settings:

```
AXES_FAILURE_LIMIT = 8
AXES_LOCKOUT_TEMPLATE = 'lockout_error.json'
AXES_COOLOFF_TIME = 4
AXES_RESET_ON_SUCCESS = True
```

On local development if we clear cache and refresh the login page, the lockout sticks. But, for some reason, on Heroku the lockout does not stick. I imagine it has something to do with how Heroku resolves IPs, but I found in the changelog:

https://django-axes.readthedocs.io/en/latest/10_changelog.html#id37

> _BREAKING CHANGES. AXES_BEHIND_REVERSE_PROXY AXES_REVERSE_PROXY_HEADER AXES_NUM_PROXIES were removed in order to use django-ipware to get the user ip address [camilonova]_

I checked the `django-ipware` project for any complaints behind "Heroku" and didn't find anything, so I'm assuming it _should be_ working. 

----------------

By turning on `AXES_ONLY_USER_FAILURES` I am seemingly able to get around the problem, but would prefer an IP-style-lockout instead of user based.

items.title: Prevent multiple call on helper function in `AxesProxyHandler.update_request`
items.body:
The `AxesProxyHandler.update_request` might be called several times during the process of user request. and for each call, this function will call 4 helper functions to get user information.
https://github.com/jazzband/django-axes/blob/cd75ef45105b12c756dac29e1b171766a5fe9293/axes/handlers/proxy.py#L56
For example:
In the user successful login process, it will be called two times:

1. In `AxesProxyHandler.is_allowed`: https://github.com/jazzband/django-axes/blob/cd75ef45105b12c756dac29e1b171766a5fe9293/axes/handlers/proxy.py#L81
2. In `AxesProxyHandler.user_logged_in` signal handler: https://github.com/jazzband/django-axes/blob/cd75ef45105b12c756dac29e1b171766a5fe9293/axes/handlers/proxy.py#L95

Solution:
    set a flag on request to prevent multiple calls on helper functions.

items.title: cooloff_time context variable is in iso8601 format
items.body:
When using a custom template (by setting the `AXES_LOCKOUT_TEMPLATE`), the template is passed `cooloff_time` as a context variable. This sounds really useful, as I can automatically display to my user "you have been locked out for X minutes/hours".

However, [the code](https://github.com/jazzband/django-axes/blob/93bb73552e522eadd2cc02512183bc05680d43bb/axes/helpers.py#L289) converts this to iso8601 format. In my case, I'm locking users out for 2 minutes, and in iso8601 this reads "You have been locked out for PT2M" - which isn't a very helpful message for the user.

I appreciate you probably want some backwards compatibility here, but what would you say to adding an additional context variable, perhaps `cooloff_timedelta`, which gives me the actual object. This would allow me to add my own formatting. Obviously I could write a template tag that interprets the iso8601 format, but that feels like a bit of a pain since you already have access to the timedelta object internally.

I'm happy to create a PR for this, but wanted to check if/how you'd like this done first.

items.title: Add Django REST Framework JSON payload support for login
items.body:
Consider the following curl request:

```
curl --request POST \
  --url http://localhost:8000/login/ \
  --header 'content-type: application/json' \
  --data '{
    "username" : "auser@foo.com",
    "password" : "dshtyh"
}'
```


Django rest framework places the data payload for the above in its `request.data` as opposed to the `request.POST` dictionary

https://www.django-rest-framework.org/tutorial/2-requests-and-responses/#request-objects

As such, any username is not picked up which practically breaks any integration that doesn't use IP or user agent to cross protect because of the following line of code

https://github.com/jazzband/django-axes/blob/master/axes/helpers.py#L145

items.title: Optimize access attempt fetching
items.body:
django-axes-5.0.13, django-1.11.23, python 3.6.5

On each login failure multiple (3x) 'Getting access attempts that are newer than' checks are performed.

Are they really neccessary? I didn't look deep enough but it seems one 'access attempt' check after 'expired access attempts' is just enough.

>2019-09-17 07:27:21 [25390] [DEBUG] AXES: Getting access attempts that are newer than 2019-09-17 06:27:21.438521+00:00
>2019-09-17 07:27:21 [25390] [INFO] AXES: Cleaned up 0 expired access attempts from database that were older than 2019-09-17 06:27:21.567521+00:00
>2019-09-17 07:27:21 [25390] [DEBUG] AXES: Getting access attempts that are newer than 2019-09-17 06:27:21.567521+00:00
>2019-09-17 07:27:21 [25390] [WARNING] AXES: Repeated login failure by {username: "user", ip_address: "127.0.0.1", user_agent: "Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64; rv:69.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/69.0", path_info: "/admin/login/"}. Count = 2 of 10. Updating existing record in the database.
>2019-09-17 07:27:21 [25390] [DEBUG] AXES: Getting access attempts that are newer than 2019-09-17 06:27:21.567521+00:00
[17/Sep/2019 07:27:21] "POST /admin/login/?next=/admin/ HTTP/1.1" 200 1810

This is a brand new clean django test project. django-axes is basically configured by default, excluding the following:
>AXES_FAILURE_LIMIT = 10
>AXES_RESET_ON_SUCCESS = True

'django.contrib.auth.backends.ModelBackend' auth backend is used.

This is my settings and views.

settings.py
```# django-axes
AXES_COOLOFF_TIME = 24
AXES_FAILURE_LIMIT = 10
AXES_HANDLER = 'axes.handlers.database.AxesDatabaseHandler'
AXES_LOCK_OUT_BY_COMBINATION_USER_AND_IP = True

AXES_META_PRECEDENCE_ORDER = ['HTTP_X_FORWARDED_FOR', 'REMOTE_ADDR']
AXES_RESET_ON_SUCCESS = True
AXES_USE_USER_AGENT = True
```

views.py
```from axes.handlers.proxy import AxesProxyHandler

def post(self, request):
        form = self.get_form()
        if not form.is_valid():
            credentials = {'username': form.cleaned_data.get('username')}
            if AxesProxyHandler.is_locked(request=request, credentials=credentials):
                tasks_access_block_send_email(email=form.cleaned_data.get('username'))

            user_login_failed.send(sender=User, request=request, credentials=credentials)

            return self.form_invalid(form)

        user = authenticate(
            request=request,
            username=form.cleaned_data.get('username'),
            password=form.cleaned_data.get('password'),
        )
        if user is not None:
            login(request, user)
            user_logged_in.send(sender=User, request=request, user=user)

            return redirect(self.get_success_url())

        credentials = {'username': form.cleaned_data.get('username')}
        user_login_failed.send(sender=User, request=request, credentials=credentials)
        return self.form_invalid(form)
```

I would like to know how I could solve it, could you please help me, thanks

items.title: Compatibility issues with DRF
items.body:
I am using:

```
djangorestframework==3.9.4
django-axes==5.0.9
Django==2.2.3
```
Problem seems to be here:

https://github.com/jazzband/django-axes/blob/master/axes/helpers.py#L371

```
def get_client_cache_key(request_or_attempt: Union[HttpRequest, Any], credentials: dict = None) -> str:
    """
    Build cache key name from request or AccessAttempt object.
    :param request_or_attempt: HttpRequest or AccessAttempt object
    :param credentials: credentials containing user information
    :return cache_key: Hash key that is usable for Django cache backends
    """

    if isinstance(request_or_attempt, HttpRequest):
        username = get_client_username(request_or_attempt, credentials)
        ip_address = get_client_ip_address(request_or_attempt)
        user_agent = get_client_user_agent(request_or_attempt)
    else:
        username = request_or_attempt.username
        ip_address = request_or_attempt.ip_address
        user_agent = request_or_attempt.user_agent

    filter_kwargs = get_client_parameters(username, ip_address, user_agent)

    cache_key_components = ''.join(value for value in filter_kwargs.values() if value)
    cache_key_digest = md5(cache_key_components.encode()).hexdigest()
    cache_key = f'axes-{cache_key_digest}'
```

Instead of having an `django.http.request.HttpRequest` I have an `rest_framework.request.Request`

If I refactor:

```
from rest_framework.request import Request

...


def get_client_cache_key(request_or_attempt: Union[HttpRequest, Any], credentials: dict = None) -> str:
    """
    Build cache key name from request or AccessAttempt object.

    :param request_or_attempt: HttpRequest or AccessAttempt object
    :param credentials: credentials containing user information
    :return cache_key: Hash key that is usable for Django cache backends
    """

    if isinstance(request_or_attempt, (HttpRequest, Request)):
        username = get_client_username(request_or_attempt, credentials)
        ip_address = get_client_ip_address(request_or_attempt)
        user_agent = get_client_user_agent(request_or_attempt)
    else:
        username = request_or_attempt.username
        ip_address = request_or_attempt.ip_address
        user_agent = request_or_attempt.user_agent

    filter_kwargs = get_client_parameters(username, ip_address, user_agent)

    cache_key_components = ''.join(value for value in filter_kwargs.values() if value)
    cache_key_digest = md5(cache_key_components.encode()).hexdigest()
    cache_key = f'axes-{cache_key_digest}'

    return cache_key
```

It works.

But this refactoring creates a funky dependency to rest_framework. How could this be properly implemented?

Note: the problem was not present with:

```
django-axes==5.0.9
```

items.title: 'WSGIRequest' object has no attribute 'axes_ip_address'
items.body:
A minority of requests to our application fail with the error `'WSGIRequest' object has no attribute 'axes_ip_address'`.

I can't figure out why the request object is not updated via the axes middleware for these requests.

JWT authentication is potentially implicated; we use a middleware to enable JWT authentication passed in via basic auth headers. We call `auth.authenticate` from this middleware, which eventually leads down into axes code via `backend.authenticate`.

I think it makes sense to add the Axes middleware BEFORE our basic auth middleware, instead of as the last middleware as documented in the installation documentation. Does that make sense?

items.title: Still get lockout message even with AXES_LOCK_OUT_AT_FAILURE set to False
items.body:
I have AXES_LOCK_OUT_AT_FAILURE set to False, which does work properly, since I can still log in using valid credentials even when I have passed the failure limit. However, if I have passed the failure limit and enter invalid credentials, then Axes still shows the lockout message (or redirect/template depending on your settings), even though the account isn't actually locked.

If AXES_LOCK_OUT_AT_FAILURE is set to False, then shouldn't Axes also suppress any lockout responses on failed logins?

items.title: Behaviour of DISABLE_ACCESS_LOG is misleading
items.body:
The docs says this :

```
AXES_DISABLE_ACCESS_LOG:  If True,  disable  all  access  logging,  so  the  admin interface will be empty. Default:False
```

However, at the current state of the code, AXES_DISABLE_ACCESS_LOG is only used in user_logged_out() function, to prevent updating logout times on success logs, and unsuccessful login attempts seem to never be logged into "Access logs" table. 
So I don't get what this setting shoudl actually control.

items.title: Bug with counting access attempts and locking out user
items.body:
Hi, I have a major problem with the current behaviour of django-axes. It invalidates the protection against brute-force login attacks.

Django is running in autocommit mode (which is default). These are the relevant axes settings:

```
AXES_ONLY_USER_FAILURES=True
AXES_FAILURE_LIMIT=5
AXES_DISABLE_SUCCESS_ACCESS_LOG=True
```

In `handlers/database.py` the access attempt counter gets updated with the following statement:

```
            attempts.update(
                get_data=Concat('get_data', Value(separator + get_data)),
                post_data=Concat('post_data', Value(separator + post_data)),
                http_accept=request.axes_http_accept,
                path_info=request.axes_path_info,
                failures_since_start=failures_since_start,
                attempt_time=request.axes_attempt_time,
            )
```
So when I try to login with a wrong password 5 times in a row, `failures_since_start` has a value of 5 and is send to the database with that update command.
As `failures_since_start` then has reached the AXES_FAILURE_LIMIT value, the following code in `handlers/database.py` purposely raises an AxesSignalPermissionDenied exception:

```
        if failures_since_start >= settings.AXES_FAILURE_LIMIT:
            log.warning('AXES: Locking out %s after repeated login failures.', client_str)

            user_locked_out.send(
                'axes',
                request=request,
                username=username,
                ip_address=request.axes_ip_address,
            )

            raise AxesSignalPermissionDenied('Locked out due to repeated login failures.')
```

My understanding is, that this exception leads the current database transaction (we are in autcommit mode!) to be rolled back. (My database log shows the ROLLBACK command sent to the database.) But that ROLLBACK resets the stored `failures_since_start` to the previous value of 4.
In effect an attacker can keep trying different passwords without any limit until he finds the right one, because `failures_since_start` never gets stored in the database as soon as it reaches the value of AXES_FAILURE_LIMIT.

First question: Is my understanding of the problem correct?
Second question: If it is, how can this problem be resolved?

Thanks!

items.title: Django test client compatibility
items.body:
Since version 5, when using the `login` and `force_login` methods of the django test client (django version 1.11), exceptions get thrown and tests fail.


When using `force_login()` the django test client uses an instance of `HttpRequest`, but axes requires an `AxesHttpRequest`.
```
from django.test import Client
client = Client()
client.force_login(user)

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/vagrant/src/project/tests/tests_integration.py", line 87, in setUp
    client.force_login(user)
  File "/home/vagrant/.local/share/virtualenvs/vagrant-gKDsaKU3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/test/client.py", line 645, in force_login
    self._login(user, backend)
  File "/home/vagrant/.local/share/virtualenvs/vagrant-gKDsaKU3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/test/client.py", line 658, in _login
    login(request, user, backend)
  File "/home/vagrant/.local/share/virtualenvs/vagrant-gKDsaKU3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/contrib/auth/__init__.py", line 161, in login
    user_logged_in.send(sender=user.__class__, request=request, user=user)
  File "/home/vagrant/.local/share/virtualenvs/vagrant-gKDsaKU3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/dispatch/dispatcher.py", line 193, in send
    for receiver in self._live_receivers(sender)
  File "/home/vagrant/.local/share/virtualenvs/vagrant-gKDsaKU3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/dispatch/dispatcher.py", line 193, in <listcomp>
    for receiver in self._live_receivers(sender)
  File "/home/vagrant/.local/share/virtualenvs/vagrant-gKDsaKU3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/axes/signals.py", line 26, in handle_user_logged_in
    AxesProxyHandler.user_logged_in(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/vagrant/.local/share/virtualenvs/vagrant-gKDsaKU3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/axes/handlers/proxy.py", line 52, in user_logged_in
    return cls.get_implementation().user_logged_in(sender, request, user, **kwargs)
  File "/home/vagrant/.local/share/virtualenvs/vagrant-gKDsaKU3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/axes/handlers/database.py", line 141, in user_logged_in
    clean_expired_user_attempts(request.axes_attempt_time)
AttributeError: 'HttpRequest' object has no attribute 'axes_attempt_time'
```


When using `login()` the test client uses `request=None` to authenticate.
```
from django.test import Client
client = Client()
client.login(user=user.email, password="SecurePassword123")

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/vagrant/src/project/tests/tests_integration.py", line 89, in setUp
    client.login(user=user.email, password="SecurePassword123")
  File "/home/vagrant/.local/share/virtualenvs/vagrant-gKDsaKU3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/test/client.py", line 628, in login
    user = authenticate(**credentials)
  File "/home/vagrant/.local/share/virtualenvs/vagrant-gKDsaKU3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/contrib/auth/__init__.py", line 70, in authenticate
    user = _authenticate_with_backend(backend, backend_path, request, credentials)
  File "/home/vagrant/.local/share/virtualenvs/vagrant-gKDsaKU3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/contrib/auth/__init__.py", line 116, in _authenticate_with_backend
    return backend.authenticate(*args, **credentials)
  File "/home/vagrant/.local/share/virtualenvs/vagrant-gKDsaKU3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/axes/backends.py", line 33, in authenticate
    raise AxesBackendRequestParameterRequired('AxesBackend requires a request as an argument to authenticate')
axes.exceptions.AxesBackendRequestParameterRequired: AxesBackend requires a request as an argument to authenticate
```

items.title: django-oauth-toolkit compatibility
items.body:
I feel like I'm being stupid here as these are both Jazzband projects but I can't get my head around how to get django-axes working with django-oauth-toolkit.

If I try and authenticate without changing anything, it will complain that 

```
File "/home/user/.virtualenvs/project/lib/python3.6/site-packages/oauth2_provider/oauth2_validators.py", line 520, in validate_user
    u = authenticate(username=username, password=password)
  File "/home/user/.virtualenvs/project/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/contrib/auth/__init__.py", line 70, in authenticate
    user = _authenticate_with_backend(backend, backend_path, request, credentials)
  File "/home/user/.virtualenvs/project/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/contrib/auth/__init__.py", line 116, in _authenticate_with_backend
    return backend.authenticate(*args, **credentials)
  File "/home/user/.virtualenvs/project/lib/python3.6/site-packages/axes/backends.py", line 37, in authenticate
    raise AxesModelBackend.RequestParameterRequired()
axes.backends.AxesModelBackend.RequestParameterRequired: AxesModelBackend requires calls to authenticate to pass `request` as an argument.
```

The cause of this can be seen quite clearly in the stacktrace - because of this call in oauth2_validators: https://github.com/jazzband/django-oauth-toolkit/blob/master/oauth2_provider/oauth2_validators.py#L615

However if I then customise DOT and set a custom validator including request in authenticate() as follows:
```
OAUTH2_PROVIDER = {
    'OAUTH2_VALIDATOR_CLASS': 'custom.app.MyOAuth2Validator',
    'SCOPES': {'read': 'Read scope', 'write': 'Write scope'},
}
class MyOAuth2Validator(OAuth2Validator):
    def validate_user(self, username, password, client, request, *args, **kwargs):
        """
        Check username and password correspond to a valid and active User
        """
        u = authenticate(request=request, username=username, password=password)
        if u is not None and u.is_active:
            request.user = u
            return True
        return False
```
it then throws the error:
```
File "/home/user/.virtualenvs/project/lib/python3.6/site-packages/axes/attempts.py", line 178, in is_already_locked
    ip = get_client_ip(request)
  File "/home/user/.virtualenvs/project/lib/python3.6/site-packages/axes/utils.py", line 69, in get_client_ip
    request_header_order=settings.AXES_META_PRECEDENCE_ORDER,
  File "/home/user/.virtualenvs/project/lib/python3.6/site-packages/ipware/ip2.py", line 25, in get_client_ip
    value = util.get_request_meta(request, key)
  File "/home/user/.virtualenvs/project/lib/python3.6/site-packages/ipware/utils.py", line 66, in get_request_meta
    value = request.META.get(key, request.META.get(key.replace('_', '-'), '')).strip()
  File "/home/user/.virtualenvs/project/lib/python3.6/site-packages/oauthlib/common.py", line 435, in __getattr__
    raise AttributeError(name)
AttributeError: META
```
This again makes sense, because the Request inside the validator is from oauthlib.common and not from Django and therefore doesn't have any META data.

How on earth are these supposed to work together??

items.title: Decide on supported Python versions
items.body:
I took a look at the [PyPI Download Stats site](https://pypistats.org/packages/django-axes) and saw that most of our downloaders are already running on Python 3.6 if they are running on Python 3.

Running on Python 3.6+ would enable:

- better type annotations that would improve readability for
  - class and instance attributes, as well as
  - local function variables,
- f-strings that would enable cleaner representations,
- ordered dictionaries that would remove the need for OrderedDicts, and
- better UTF-8 support.

Django has also dropped support for Python 3.5 in upstream and most distributions offer Python 3.6 as the default Python 3 version, so I think there is a strong case for upgrading straight to 3.6.

As version 5.0 is coming closer to release with most wanted features being implemented, I think this change should be implemented in there. Python 3.4 and 3.5 still have some grace period left in their support, but I think running the latest version should be the norm.

items.title: Improve request attribute calculation
items.body:
Improve the middleware (or the handler) implementation so that it calculates the necessary request attributes once instead of calculating them again at every usage. 

The following attributes can be calculated once per request:

- `request.axes_attempt_time` can be a `datetime.datetime` stamp
- `request.axes_ip_address` can be a validated `ipaddress.IPV4Address`
- `request.axes_user_agent` can be a string indicating the user agent
- `request.axes_path_info` can be a string indicating the path
- `request.axes_http_accept` can be a string indicating the accept value

items.title: Improve database and cache handler codebase
items.body: Improve the internal handler implementations of the database and cache handler and remove duplicate code.

items.title: Improve base handler class implementation
items.body:
Improve the handler base class and make it an abstract base class or `abc.ABC` with correctly marked `abc.abstractmethods`. 

This requires refactoring the test suite for the handlers.

items.title: Improve documentation for base project and custom handlers
items.body:
The documentation should have the 

- initial tutorial for setup, 
- how-to guide for writing custom handlers, 
- explanation of functionality, and 
- technical reference for the project.

More information at https://www.divio.com/blog/documentation/

items.title: Update author, contributor, and licence information
items.body:
Currently we have some outdated and mismatching author and copyright information in a few different places for the Axes project:

- the [LICENSE file](https://github.com/jazzband/django-axes/blob/master/LICENSE) lists copyright holders Josh VanderLinden for 2008 and Philip Neustrom for 2009, but no mentions after that,
- the [setup file](https://github.com/jazzband/django-axes/blob/master/setup.py) lists a lot more authors, and
- the [documentation configuration file](https://github.com/jazzband/django-axes/blob/master/docs/conf.py) lists only the Jazzband organization with year 2016.

Ideally, the author and copyright information could be harmonized so that it would be easier for users to know who has copyright on what parts of the program and what kind of authorship should be mentioned for the project.

Should the project just list Jazzband organization as the copyright holder and author from 2016 onwards and refer communications to the Jazzband organization? Is there a mailing list that could be used in e.g. the `setup.py` file for the `author` field? Can the `LICENSE` file just be updated with more recent data, and is Jazzband a proper entry in there?

@jezdez @camilonova do you know how the copyright notices, authorship, and licensing should be handled in the Jazzband projects?

The main reason I am bringing this up is that I think it would be nice to have all parts of the project referring to the same information in the same fashion. 

Documenting the usable practices in the Jazzband organization for these things would also be nice, at least I didn't find any mentions on licensing or authorship on the Jazzband site.

items.title: GET requests always skipping lockout check
items.body:
Hi. I'm using `django-axes` in a HTTP API with Basic Auth. The API accepts `GET` and `POST` requests, and all requests have the Basic Auth header to extract credentials from. To integrate with `django-axes`, I pass the credentials manually into `django.contrib.auth.authenticate` (using the `username` and `password` parameters) and have `AxesModelBackend` included in `AUTHENTICATION_BACKENDS`.

This has seemingly worked fine up until recently, when I upgraded `django-axes` from 2.3.3 to 4.4.0. After upgrading, I've noticed that GET requests are no longer subject to lockout, and found this change to be the reason: https://github.com/jazzband/django-axes/pull/262/files#diff-98c00a3d39f41b919aeb159f2b5dd247R436

I understand why the change was made (https://github.com/jazzband/django-axes/issues/261) but was wondering if it could be extended slightly to still support checking `GET` requests under certain conditions. I think, with the latest version of `django-axes` (https://github.com/jazzband/django-axes/blob/4.5.4/axes/attempts.py#L183), something like `(request.method == 'GET' and credentials is None)` would work for me and still address https://github.com/jazzband/django-axes/issues/261.

I'm happy to open a PR if this is considered a valid issue but wanted to ask for advice first.

Thanks.

items.title: Python 2.7 support ends on 2020-01-01
items.body:
As Python 2.7 EOL is closing in I am opening this ticket to remind everybody to upgrade their Python 2.7 Django projects to a supported Python 3 version.

This package will be dropping support for Python 2.7 on 2020-01-01 and removing support from the CI test matrix, file encodings, old packages and so forth, effectively declaring Python 2.7 untested and unsecure in favor of speeding up development in Python 3.5+ for this package.

https://pythonclock.org/

items.title: Use signals and authentication backend for attempt monitoring and lockouts
items.body:
Implement the user login attempt monitoring and lockouts as an authentication backend instead of using the current approach of decorating all the views the user might use. 

Listen for signals for user login and logout events for attempt tracking.

Implement the authentication backend as an reusable and customisable class that users of this package can specialize to fit their own needs.

Possibly refactor the current APIs to wrap the request and credentials as discussed in https://github.com/jazzband/django-axes/pull/377 and make the requests and credentials resolver pluggable and extensible as well.

Design and document the authentication APIs so that they have clear entrypoints and expected return values and are easy to customize and extend.

items.title: Static type annotations and checks with mypy
items.body:
We could implement type checking for the library with mypy to enforce the old APIs that will be under refactoring discussed in #377 to be well-typed:

https://mypy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/python2.html

I think that the library is so small that implementing the explicit type signatures and adding mypy checks to the Travis CI pipeline would be a low hanging fruit that can improve the package quality and help with integrations. 

I think at the very least all of the external APIs that can be extended by users should be well-typed.

items.title: axes_reset doesn't clear the cache.
items.body:
I'll fix this if I get to it, but in case anyone else has time, go for it. I'd also appreciate input here on the design question below.

### The Issue
In `utils.reset` we don't clear the cache, so even if it is cleared,  lockouts persist until cache expires.
We don't want to reset the whole cache if we're clearing doe just one username, but I'm not sure on the best approach

### Approach 1
Add cache key revocation in an `AccessAttempt` `post_delete` signal. This would require closer coupling the cache key logic and the `AccessAttempt`, which I'm fine with since the cache is used to retrieve AccessAttempts and the decoupling is what caused the issue. The con is that since signals are async, the management command will return before the full cleanup is done which may be misleading to the caller as there will be a delay. We could attach another signal and wait, but that's kinda gross.

### Approach 2
Keep the cache logic separate from `AccessAttempt` and do a looped delete instead of bulk delete in `reset`, for an ip or username specific reset, deleting the cache keys as we loop. the filtered data shouldn't be too big so It shouldn't be too much of a performance hit.

items.title: Should axes use the request.POST data or authenticate's **credentials?
items.body:
In my use case, I process the POST to get the user we pass to `authenticate` from different endpoints in different ways. This is a hassle to reproduce in `AXES_USERNAME_CALLABLE`. I think instead, we should pull username and password from the args passed to authenticate instead of from the `request.POST`. Furthermore, request being present depends on it being correctly passed by 3rd party backends even though Django mentions it is an optional parm in the docs.

Input? @camilonova @aleksihakli @aclark4life @codekoala

items.title: Handling unicode characters in User-agent string
items.body:
It is a really minor issue but when checking my error logs I noticed errors related to django-axes when someone has unicode characters in their user-agent string (I suspect pentesters).

For instance the user-agent string `\ð\'\'\ð""` triggers a UnicodeDecodeError at this line https://github.com/jazzband/django-axes/blob/master/axes/attempts.py#L69
```
Exception Type: UnicodeDecodeError at /login/
Exception Value: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc3 in position 1: ordinal not in range(128)
```

It could be related to the fact I'm still using Python 2.7.12 tho, but having unicode support with that version would be nice.

Thanks.

items.title: Docs outdated about DRF not passing request to authenticate
items.body:
I've noticed that a claim in the documentation might be outdated. When discussing the issues with authentication, it blames the DRF as it does not pass the request to the `authenticate` function. This might be true in the past, but I think [it's not the case anymore](https://github.com/encode/django-rest-framework/blob/master/rest_framework/authentication.py#L97) ([commit](https://github.com/encode/django-rest-framework/commit/161dc2df2ccecc5307cdbc05ef6159afd614189e)), as it was fixed in version `3.7.0`.

https://django-axes.readthedocs.io/en/latest/configuration.html#authentication-backend-problems
`Notably Django Rest Framework (DRF) BasicAuthentication does not pass request. Here is an example workaround for DRF.`

Can anybody confirm this, so I can remove this comment from the docs? Thanks.

items.title: Log in attempts are not consecutive
items.body:
I am using django-axes 4.1.0. I set  The number of failed login attempts to 5 attempts to block the user. I noticed that the login attempts are not consecutive. If the user does 4 failed login attempts followed by 1 successful attempts and then 1 failing attempt, he will be blocked all the same. 

After reviewing possible configurations for django-axes I noticed that there is no possible config I could use to enforce the behaviour I need. Is there a way to force this required behaviour? If not I would regard this as an issue, because it is more  intuitive to force the attempts to be consecutive or at least make this option configurable.
